Notes: Intimate imperative used between close people (romantic partners, family). Example: 'Abrázame fuerte que estoy triste' (Hug me tight, I'm sad)

Formal way to accept an invitation. Colombian social etiquette values gracious acceptance. Example: 'Acepto la invitación con mucho gusto, gracias' (I accept the invitation with much pleasure, thanks)
Imperative to move nearer. Can be romantic ('Acércate, quiero besarte') or neutral ('Acércate para que te vea'). Context determines tone.
Alternative: Imperative to move nearer | Can be romantic or neutral

Notes: Beach question about umbrella rental. 'Sombrilla' is standard in Colombia. Common at Cartagena, Santa Marta beaches. Example: '¿Alquilamos sombrilla? El sol está muy fuerte'
Means 'previous' or 'before'. Used in: navigation ('la página anterior'), time ('el día anterior'), anatomy ('la parte anterior del cuerpo'). Example: 'Vuelve a la página anterior'
Colombian expression of surprise, pleasure, or pain. NOT literal parent reference. Can be flirty ('Ay papá, qué rico') or express pain ('Ay mamá, eso duele'). Very Colombian.
Alternative: Expression of emotion | Not literal parent

Notes: Term of endearment for romantic partner or actual baby. Extremely common in Colombian relationships. Example: 'Hola bebé, cómo estás mi amor?' (Hi baby, how are you my love?)
Alternative: Term of endearment | For partner or child

Back (EN): Good or not? / Alright or not?
Notes: Casual way to ask if something is okay/acceptable. Checking agreement. Example: 'Nos vemos a las 8, ¿bien o no?' (See you at 8, good or not?)

Back (EN): Good or terrible? / All or nothing
Notes: Colombian slang: 'good or terrible' - no middle ground. 'Pal perro' = for the dog (really bad). Example: 'Este partido es bien o pal perro' (This match is either good or terrible)
Making a toast with drinks. Important in Colombian social culture. Example: '¡Brindamos por la vida y la salud!' (Let's toast to life and health!)
Casual Colombian greeting. 'Buenas' = short for buenos días/tardes. 'Cómo vas' = how are you going. Example: 'Buenas cómo vas, parcero, todo bien?' (Hey how's it going, buddy, all good?)
Intimate imperative between romantic partners. Example: 'Bésame antes de irte, te voy a extrañar' (Kiss me before you go, I'll miss you)

Back (EN): Kiss me all over / Kiss all of me
Notes: Intimate/romantic request. 'Todo' = all/everything. Used in passionate moments. Example: 'Bésame todo, no dejes ningún lugar sin besar'
Chilean slang (not pure Colombian) from English 'catch'. In Colombia, 'entiendes?' or 'captas?' more common. Example: '¿Cachái lo que digo?' (You get what I'm saying?)

Front (ES): Cada día entiendo un poquito más
Back (EN): Every day I understand a little more
Notes: Expression of gradual learning. Colombian use of 'poquito' (diminutive). Example: 'Cada día entiendo un poquito más el acento paisa' (Every day I understand the paisa accent a little more)

Back (EN): Let's walk along the shore / We walk along the shore
Notes: Beach/riverside activity. 'Orilla' = shore/edge. Romantic activity. Example: 'Caminamos por la orilla viendo el atardecer' (We walk along the shore watching the sunset)

Back (EN): Let's walk for a bit / Let's take a walk
Notes: Suggestion to walk together. 'Un rato' = a while. Common social activity. Example: 'Caminemos un rato por el parque, hace lindo' (Let's walk for a bit through the park, it's nice out)
The number 100. Before singular masculine nouns: 'cien' (not 'ciento'). Example: 'Cien pesos' (100 pesos), 'Ciento veinte' (120)
100,000. With pesos, ~$25 USD (2025). Common amount. Example: 'El taxi me costó cien mil pesos' (The taxi cost me 100k pesos)
Specific currency amount. ~$25 USD (2025). Common bill. Example: 'Te presto cien mil pesos para el almuerzo' (I'll lend you 100k pesos for lunch)
5,000. With pesos, ~$1.25 USD (2025). Very small amount. Example: 'Un tinto cuesta cinco mil pesos' (A coffee costs 5k pesos)
The number 50. Example: 'Mi mamá tiene cincuenta años' (My mom is fifty years old)
50,000. With pesos, ~$12.50 USD (2025). Common for meals, taxis. Example: 'El almuerzo sale cincuenta mil pesos' (Lunch costs 50k pesos)

Back (EN): Let's eat something / Should we eat something?
Notes: Casual suggestion to eat. Common social invitation. Example: '¿Comemos algo antes del cine?' (Should we eat something before the movies?)

Back (EN): About five minutes / Around five minutes away
Notes: 'Como' = approximately. Time/distance estimate. Example: 'Estoy como a cinco minutos de llegar' (I'm about five minutes away from arriving)
Approximate time. 'Como' softens (not exact). Example: 'Te paso recogiendo como a las cinco' (I'll pick you up around five)

Back (EN): Whatever you say / As you say
Notes: Informal agreement, deferring to other's preference. Can sound passive-aggressive with wrong tone. Example: 'Como tú digas, mi amor' (Whatever you say, my love)

Back (EN): Whatever you prefer / However you prefer
Notes: Letting other person choose. More polite than 'como tú digas'. Example: 'Como tú prefieras, yo me adapto' (However you prefer, I'll adapt)
Suggestion/statement about sharing. Colombian culture values sharing. Example: '¿Compartimos la cuenta?' (Should we split the bill?) or '¿Compartimos este postre?' (Should we share this dessert?)
Warning or instruction to be cautious. Example: 'Maneja con cuidado, está lloviendo' (Drive carefully, it's raining)

Back (EN): Who are you coming with? / Who did you come with?
Notes: Question about companion. 'Venir' can be present or recent past in Colombian Spanish. Example: '¿Con quién vienes a la fiesta?' (Who are you coming to the party with?)
Imperative challenge to persuade. Can be playful or serious. Example: 'Convénceme de que vale la pena ir' (Convince me it's worth going)

Back (EN): I think I need intensive therapy / I think I need ICU
Notes: Humorous/dramatic expression when overwhelmed. 'Terapia intensiva' = ICU, used metaphorically. Example after stressful day or intense attraction. 'Después de esa rumba creo que necesito terapia intensiva'
The number 40. Example: 'Tengo cuarenta años' (I'm forty years old)
Multiple meanings: 1) Room/bedroom ('Mi cuarto está limpio') 2) Quarter 1/4 ('Un cuarto de pizza') 3) Fourth/4th ('El cuarto piso'). Context determines meaning.
Time expression. 'Cuarto para' = quarter to. Example: 'Es cuarto para las cuatro, apurémonos' (It's quarter to four, let's hurry)

Back (EN): Watch out for the cars / Be careful with the cars
Notes: Traffic warning. Colombian traffic can be chaotic, especially in Bogotá, Cali. Example: 'Cuidado con los carros cuando cruces la calle' (Watch out for cars when you cross the street)

Back (EN): How much is left? / How much longer?
Notes: Question about remaining time/distance/quantity. Example: '¿Cuánto falta para llegar?' (How much longer until we arrive?)
Emergency situation. From medical/military terminology. Used seriously or humorously. Example: '¡Código rojo! Se acabó la cerveza en la fiesta' (Code red! The beer ran out at the party)

Back (EN): How so? / What do you mean? / How come?
Notes: Very common Colombian expression asking for explanation/clarification. Example: '¿Cómo así que no vienes? Te estaba esperando' (What do you mean you're not coming? I was waiting for you)

Front (ES): Cómo se dice esto bien en Colombia
Back (EN): How do you say this properly in Colombia?
Notes: Question about Colombian Spanish usage. Shows cultural awareness of regional differences. Used by language learners. Example: '¿Cómo se dice esto bien en Colombia? Quiero hablar como ustedes'
Friendly check-in question. More specific than '¿cómo estás?'. Example: 'Hola amor, ¿cómo va tu día? Ya almorzaste?' (Hi love, how's your day? Have you had lunch yet?)
Evening/night check-in. Common in nightlife context. Example: '¿Cómo va tu noche? ¿La estás pasando bien?' (How's your night? Are you having a good time?)

Back (EN): Turn around / Go around / Make a U-turn
Notes: Direction instruction. Can mean turn around (physically) or U-turn (driving). Example: 'Da la vuelta en la esquina' (Turn around at the corner) or 'Da la vuelta al edificio' (Go around the building)
Request for brief wait. Colombian 'five minutes' can be... flexible! Often means 10-15 minutes. Example: 'Dame cinco minutos y salgo' (Give me five minutes and I'll come out)
Request for a drink. 'De beber' = infinitive form (to drink). Example: 'Tengo sed, dame de beber algo frío' (I'm thirsty, give me something cold to drink)
Request for additional quantity. Can be food, drink, or metaphorical. Example: 'Esta comida está deliciosa, dame más' (This food is delicious, give me more)
Asking for someone's opinion/assessment. Can be literal (medical) or metaphorical. Example: 'Dame tu diagnóstico de la situación, qué opinas?' (Give me your take on the situation, what do you think?)
Expression of surprise OR emphasis. As question: '¿De verdad?' (Really?). As statement: 'De verdad te amo' (I truly love you). Very common.

Front (ES): Debe ser ilegal ser tan lindalindo
Back (EN): It should be illegal to be so beautiful/handsome
Notes: Flirtatious compliment. Playful exaggeration common in Colombian flirting. Example: 'Debe ser ilegal ser tan linda, deberían arrestarte por robar corazones' (It should be illegal to be so beautiful, they should arrest you for stealing hearts)

Back (EN): They should ban you / You should be prohibited
Notes: Flirtatious expression meaning dangerously attractive. Example: 'Deberían prohibirte salir así de hermosa' (They should ban you from going out looking so gorgeous)

Back (EN): Show me / Prove it to me / Demonstrate to me
Notes: Challenge to demonstrate or prove. Can be playful or serious. Example: 'Dices que cocinas bien, demuéstrame' (You say you cook well, show me) or romantic: 'Demuéstrame que me quieres' (Show me you love me)

Front (ES): Desde que llegaste todo es más bonito
Back (EN): Since you arrived, everything is more beautiful
Notes: Romantic expression about someone's positive impact. Colombian poetic style. Example: 'Desde que llegaste todo es más bonito, mi vida cambió completamente' (Since you arrived everything is more beautiful, my life changed completely)

Back (EN): Let's unwrap the gift / We unwrap the present
Notes: Action of opening wrapped gift. 'Desenvolver' = unwrap. Example: 'Desenvolvemos el regalo todos juntos para ver qué es' (Let's all unwrap the gift together to see what it is)
Preposition indicating position. Example: 'Está detrás de la puerta' (It's behind the door) or 'Camina detrás de mí' (Walk behind me)
Imperative to return. Colombian use of reflexive 'devolverse'. Example: '¡Devuélvete, te olvidaste las llaves!' (Come back, you forgot your keys!)
Imperative request. Can be intimate/romantic or about recognition. Example (romantic): 'Di mi nombre, quiero escucharlo de tus labios' (Say my name, I want to hear it from your lips)
Alternative: Say my name | Can be intimate

Notes: Slang for someone mischievous, seductive, wild. Often complimentary in flirting. Example: 'Esa diabla me tiene loco' (That she-devil has me crazy) means irresistibly tempting.
10,000. With pesos, ~$2.50 USD (2025). Example: 'El pasaje del bus cuesta diez mil pesos' (The bus fare costs 10k pesos)
Invitation to be present and enjoy now. Colombian emphasis on living in the moment. Example: 'No pienses en mañana, disfrutemos el momento' (Don't think about tomorrow, let's enjoy the moment)
Alternative: Live in the moment | Enjoy now

Notes: Two meanings: 1) Double amount ('Dame doble porción') 2) Turn left/right driving ('Doble a la derecha'). Context determines meaning.
2,000. With pesos, ~$0.50 USD (2025). Very small amount. Example: 'Te debo dos mil pesos del bus' (I owe you 2k pesos from the bus)
The number 200. Example: 'Doscientos mil pesos' (200,000 pesos - about $50 USD in 2025)

Suggestion to sleep in same space. Can be innocent (share accommodation) or romantic/sexual. Context matters. Example: 'Hace frío, durmamos juntos para calentarnos' (It's cold, let's sleep together to warm up)

Back (EN): Give me everything / Give it all to me
Notes: Request for everything/the whole thing. Can be literal (food, object) or figurative/passionate. Example: 'Dámelo todo, no me dejes con ganas' (Give me everything, don't leave me wanting)

Back (EN): Let me try you / Let me taste you
Notes: Can mean taste (food: 'Déjame probarte este plato') or intimate/sensual context. 'Probar' = try/taste. Meaning depends on context.
Time reference to previous year. Example: 'El año pasado viajé a Cartagena' (Last year I traveled to Cartagena)

Front (ES): El cielo está de luto porque perdió una
Back (EN): The sky is in mourning because it lost a star
Notes: Romantic/cheesy pickup line. Implies person is so beautiful they're the star that fell from heaven. Common in Colombian flirting culture despite being cliché.

Front (ES): El descanso se hace en la pista
Back (EN): You rest on the dance floor / Rest happens while dancing
Notes: Colombian party culture saying: real rest happens dancing (ironic). Party mentality - don't stop even when tired. Response to someone saying they're tired at rumba.

Front (ES): El mar está fuerte mejor acá bajito
Back (EN): The sea is rough, better stay in the shallow area / The ocean is rough, better here in the shallow
Notes: Beach safety advice. 'Fuerte' = strong/rough waves. 'Bajito' = shallow area. Example: 'El mar está fuerte mejor acá bajito con los niños' (The sea is rough, better here in the shallow with the kids)

Front (ES): El mejor descanso es rumbear más
Back (EN): The best rest is to party more
Notes: Colombian party philosophy: cure tiredness by partying harder. 'Rumbear' = Colombian slang for partying. Humorous/ironic party saying.
Future time reference. Example: 'El mes que viene es mi cumpleaños' (Next month is my birthday)
English phrase used in Spanish. Means persevere despite difficulties. Example: 'Aunque haya problemas, el show debe continuar' (Even though there are problems, the show must go on)

Humorous/playful way to invite someone to your room. Can be genuine emergency or flirtatious code. Example: 'Tengo una emergencia en mi cuarto, solo tú puedes ayudarme' (I have an emergency in my room, only you can help me)
Alternative: Playful room invitation | Can be flirty

Notes: Expression of seriousness or seeking confirmation. Example: '¿En serio?' (Seriously?) or 'En serio te lo digo' (I'm telling you seriously)

Back (EN): In a little moment / In just a sec
Notes: Colombian diminutive of 'momento'. Means very soon/shortly. Colombian time can be flexible - 'momentico' can be 5-30 minutes! Example: 'Estoy listo en un momentico'

Back (EN): So what? / So what's up? / What then?
Notes: Multiple uses: 1) Asking what's the plan ('¿Entonces qué? ¿Vamos?') 2) Challenging 'so what?'. Context/tone determines meaning.
Imperative invitation to enter. Example: 'Entra, la puerta está abierta' (Come in, the door is open) or 'Entra y ponte cómodo' (Come in and make yourself comfortable)

Back (EN): Send me the location / Send me your location
Notes: Request for GPS location/address. Very common with WhatsApp usage in Colombia. Example: 'Envíame la ubicación del restaurante por WhatsApp' (Send me the restaurant location via WhatsApp)

Often part of 'Eres como el agua para el chocolate' (like water for chocolate - reference to novel, means someone who makes you boil/passionate). Or: 'Eres como el agua que necesito para vivir' (You're like the water I need to live)

Front (ES): Eres como el aguardiente me subes direct
Back (EN): You're like aguardiente, you go straight to my head
Notes: Flirtatious comparison to strong Colombian alcohol. 'Me subes directo' = you go straight to my head/you intoxicate me quickly. Example: 'Eres como el aguardiente me subes directo y me pones loco'

Back (EN): You're too cool / You're really awesome
Notes: Colombian slang compliment. 'Bacana' = cool/awesome. 'Demasiado' = too much (positive). Example: 'Eres demasiado bacana, me caes súper bien' (You're really awesome, I really like you)
Can mean: 1) You're out of my league 2) You're overwhelming (positive/admiring). Example: 'Eres demasiado para mí, no merezco tanta belleza' (You're too much for me, I don't deserve such beauty)

Flirtatious/playful accusation. Means tempting, mischievous, irresistible. Usually positive in romantic context. Example: 'Eres el diablo, me tienes completamente tentado' (You're the devil, you have me completely tempted)
Affectionate declaration of importance. Example: 'Eres especial para mí, nunca lo olvides' (You're special to me, never forget it)

Flirtatious slang meaning 'too good to be true' or 'so attractive it should be illegal'. Example: 'Eres ilegal, deberían arrestarte por ser tan hermosa' (You're illegal, they should arrest you for being so beautiful)
Alternative: Flirty: too good to be true

Front (ES): Eres la razón por la que el café colombi
Back (EN): You're the reason Colombian coffee is so good
Notes: Poetic/humorous compliment connecting person to Colombia's famous coffee. Implies they're the essence of Colombian greatness. Cheesy but sweet pickup line.

Front (ES): Eres lo mejor que me ha pasado
Back (EN): You're the best thing that's happened to me
Notes: Deep romantic declaration. Statement of how important someone is. Example: 'Eres lo mejor que me ha pasado en la vida, gracias por existir' (You're the best thing that's happened to me in life, thanks for existing)
Metaphor meaning someone heals/helps you. Romantic or friendly. Example: 'Eres medicina para mí, siempre me haces sentir mejor' (You're medicine for me, you always make me feel better)

Front (ES): Eres mi paz y mi alegría
Back (EN): You're my peace and my joy
Notes: Deep affectionate expression. Someone brings both calm and happiness. Example: 'Eres mi paz y mi alegría, no sé qué haría sin ti' (You're my peace and my joy, I don't know what I'd do without you)

Flirtatious food metaphor. Colombian culture loves food, so comparing to favorite dish is high compliment. Can be sensual. Example: 'Eres mi plato favorito, te comería todo el día' (You're my favorite dish, I'd eat you all day)
Alternative: Flirty food metaphor | Can be sensual

Notes: Sweet/flirtatious food metaphor. Implies sweet, delicious, a treat. Example: 'Eres mi postre favorito, siempre te guardo para el final' (You're my favorite dessert, I always save you for last)

Front (ES): Eres más dulce que el arequipe
Notes: Compliment comparing to arequipe (Colombian dulce de leche/caramel). Arequipe is very sweet, so high compliment. Example: 'Eres más dulce que el arequipe, me encantas' (You're sweeter than arequipe, I love you)
Possessive romantic declaration. Shows exclusivity/commitment. Example: 'Eres mía y de nadie más' (You're mine and nobody else's). Can be sweet or intense.
High compliment comparing to deity. Implies extraordinary beauty/perfection. Example: 'Eres una diosa, nunca he visto alguien tan hermosa' (You're a goddess, I've never seen anyone so beautiful)
Flirtatious statement implying irresistibly attractive. Example: 'Eres una tentación, no puedo resistirme a ti' (You're a temptation, I can't resist you)
Compliment about being one-of-a-kind/special. Example: 'Eres única, no hay nadie como tú en el mundo' (You're unique, there's nobody like you in the world)
Statement about complex situation. Often relationship status. Example: '¿Estás soltero?' - 'Es complicado' (Are you single? - It's complicated)
Clarifying something is an invitation. Can be direct or suggestive. Example: 'Es una invitación a mi casa, ¿aceptas?' (It's an invitation to my house, do you accept?)

Back (EN): That's all / That's it / That's everything
Notes: Statement of completion or finality. Example: 'Eso es todo, no hay más' (That's all, there's no more) or 'Eso es todo lo que necesito' (That's all I need)

Back (EN): That was a blast / That was wild fun
Notes: Colombian slang. 'Recocha' = wild fun, playful chaos, great time. Example: 'Esa fiesta fue una recocha, nos divertimos muchísimo' (That party was a blast, we had so much fun)

Back (EN): Let's wait a bit / Let's hold on a moment
Notes: Suggestion to wait. 'Un poco' = a bit/a little while. Example: 'Esperemos un poco a ver si llega' (Let's wait a bit to see if they arrive)
Imperative request to wait. Example: '¡Espérame! Voy detrás de ti' (Wait for me! I'm coming behind you) or 'Espérame un segundo' (Wait for me a second)

Back (EN): Let's study anatomy / We study anatomy
Notes: Can be literal (medical/biology study) or flirtatious euphemism for physical exploration. Example (flirty): 'Estudiamos anatomía esta noche?' means exploring each other's bodies.
Alternative: Literal study | Can be flirty euphemism

Back (EN): It was incredible / That was amazing
Notes: Past tense praise/reaction. Example: 'La fiesta estuvo increíble' (The party was incredible) or 'El concierto estuvo increíble' (The concert was amazing)

Back (EN): It's fine like this / That's good as is
Notes: Acceptance of current state. Example: 'No cambies nada, está bien así' (Don't change anything, it's fine like this)

Back (EN): It's very close / It's right nearby
Notes: Colombian diminutive of 'cerca'. Means very close/nearby. Example: 'El restaurante está cerquita, podemos caminar' (The restaurant is very close, we can walk)
Weather observation. Common in Colombian lowlands (Cartagena, Cali). Example: 'Está haciendo mucho calor, vamos a la piscina' (It's very hot, let's go to the pool)
Weather observation. Common in Bogotá, highlands. Example: 'Está haciendo frío, trae chaqueta' (It's cold, bring a jacket)

Back (EN): It's pretty far / It's quite far away
Notes: Colombian diminutive of 'lejos'. Soften 'far' with diminutive. Example: 'Está lejitos, mejor tomemos un taxi' (It's pretty far, better take a taxi)
Strong attraction compliment to a woman. 'Buenísima' = superlative of 'buena' (hot/attractive). Can be objectifying, context matters. Example (among friends): 'Esa mujer está buenísima'
Strong attraction compliment to a man. 'Buenísimo' = superlative of 'bueno' (hot/attractive). Example: 'Ese man está buenísimo' (That guy is smoking hot)

Back (EN): You're provoking me / You're tempting me / You're teasing me
Notes: Accusation of provocation/temptation. Can be flirtatious or serious. Example (flirty): 'Estás provocándome con esa ropa' (You're provoking me with those clothes)
Imperative request to examine. Can be medical or flirtatious ('doctor/patient' roleplay). Example (medical): 'Doctor, examiname la garganta' or (flirty): 'Examiname completo, doctor'
Short for 'fotografía'. Example: 'Tomemos una foto' (Let's take a photo) or '¿Me mandas foto?' (Will you send me a photo?)
Animal cat. Also Colombian slang for 'servant' or 'person who does errands', but primarily means cat. Example: 'Tengo un gato en casa' (I have a cat at home)
Alternative: Cat | Also slang for servant/errand person

Back (EN): A while ago / Some time ago
Notes: Time expression meaning 'a while ago'. Example: 'Te llamé hace rato pero no contestaste' (I called you a while ago but you didn't answer)

Back (EN): A moment ago / Just a moment ago
Notes: Colombian diminutive. Recent past. Example: 'Llegó hace un momentico' (He/she arrived just a moment ago)

Back (EN): Let's exercise / We exercise / Should we work out?
Notes: Suggestion or statement about exercising. Can be literal or euphemism. Example: '¿Hacemos ejercicio en el gimnasio?' (Should we work out at the gym?) or flirty: 'Hacemos ejercicio en mi cuarto?' (sexual euphemism)

Back (EN): Acting like a monkey / Fooling around / Being silly
Notes: Colombian expression. 'Mico' = monkey. Means acting silly/foolishly. Example: 'Deja de hacer la de mico y ponte serio' (Stop fooling around and get serious)
Suggestion for romantic activity. Example: 'Hagamos algo romántico esta noche, cenemos con velas' (Let's do something romantic tonight, let's have dinner by candlelight)
Exercise suggestion. Can be literal (running, gym) or sexual euphemism. Example literal: 'Hagamos cardio en el parque' or euphemism (sex as cardio workout).

Back (EN): Fed up / Tired of it / Had enough
Notes: Colombian diminutive of 'harto'. Means fed up/tired. Example: 'Estoy hartico de este trabajo' (I'm fed up with this job)

Front (ES): Hay algo que pueda hacer para ayudarte
Back (EN): Is there anything I can do to help you?
Notes: Offer of assistance. Polite and caring. Example: '¿Hay algo que pueda hacer para ayudarte con tu problema?' (Is there anything I can do to help you with your problem?)

Back (EN): There's a discount for cash / Cash discount available
Notes: Common in Colombian commerce. Cash often gets discount vs. card. Example: '¿Hay descuento en efectivo? Puedo pagar en billetes' (Is there a cash discount? I can pay in bills)
Alternative: Cash discount inquiry | Common in Colombia

Back (EN): We have to take care of ourselves / We need to be careful
Notes: Statement about needing caution/care. Can be health, safety, or relationship. Example: 'Hay que cuidarnos, usar protección' (We have to take care of ourselves, use protection)
Colombian word for traffic jam is 'trancón'. Very common in Bogotá. Example: 'Hay trancón en la 80, mejor toma otra ruta' (There's a traffic jam on 80th, better take another route)

Back (EN): Did I do something to make you uncomfortable?
Notes: Question checking if action caused discomfort. Example: '¿Hice algo para incomodarte? No era mi intención' (Did I do something to make you uncomfortable? It wasn't my intention)

Front (ES): Hice algo para que te emberracaras conmi
Back (EN): Did I do something to make you mad at me?
Notes: Colombian 'emberracarse' = get mad/angry. Example: '¿Hice algo para que te emberracaras conmigo? Estás muy callada' (Did I do something to make you mad at me? You're very quiet)
Alternative: Colombian: did I make you mad?

Notes: Intimate/sexual request. 'Sucio' = dirty. Example used in intimate contexts for dirty talk.

Back (EN): Go ahead then / Sure, let's do it / Alright then
Notes: Colombian expression of agreement/encouragement. 'Hágale' = do it. Example: '¿Vamos al cine?' - 'Hágale pues' (Shall we go to the movies? - Sure, let's do it)
Imperative request. Can be various contexts - sensual, or asking someone to do something for you. Example: 'Házmelo como te lo pedí' (Do it to me as I asked you)
Alternative: Do it to me | Various contexts

Notes: Statement that something cannot be done. Example: 'Es imposible llegar a tiempo con este trancón' (It's impossible to arrive on time with this traffic)

Back (EN): Haha how funny / That's so funny
Notes: Laugh reaction. 'Qué risa' = how funny. Example: 'Jaja qué risa, me hiciste reír mucho' (Haha how funny, you made me laugh so much)

Back (EN): Let's play / We play / Should we play?
Notes: Suggestion or statement about playing. Can be games or flirtatious. Example: '¿Jugamos cartas?' (Should we play cards?) or flirty: '¿Jugamos un juego?'
Children's game OR adult flirtatious/sexual roleplay. 'Doctor/patient' scenario. Context determines meaning. Example (adult): 'Jugamos al doctor esta noche?' (sexual roleplay)
Adverb meaning together. Example: 'Estemos juntos siempre' (Let's be together always) or 'Vamos juntos' (Let's go together)
Imperative 'swear it' or question 'really?'. Example: '¿Jura que es verdad?' (Swear it's true?) or 'Jura que me quieres' (Swear you love me)

Back (EN): Right there / Just there / Exactly there
Notes: Precise location indication. Example: 'Ponlo justo ahí' (Put it right there) or sensual: 'Justo ahí, no pares' (Right there, don't stop)
Statement about enjoying current activity. Example: 'La estamos pasando bien en esta fiesta' (We're having a good time at this party)

Colombian greeting/conversation filler. 'Qué más' = what else/what's up. Example: 'Qué más pues, todo bien?' (What's up then, all good?)
Getting-to-know-you question. Example: '¿Qué música te gusta? ¿Eres más de salsa o reggaeton?' (What music do you like? Are you more into salsa or reggaeton?)

Back (EN): How cool / That's awesome / What a vibe
Notes: Colombian slang. 'Nota' = cool/awesome. Example: 'Esa fiesta estuvo qué nota' (That party was awesome)

Back (EN): How cool / That's awesome / What a vibe
Notes: Colombian slang. 'Nota' = cool/awesome. Example: 'Esa fiesta estuvo qué nota' (That party was awesome)
Compliment. Example: 'Qué ojos tan lindos tienes, me encanta tu mirada' (What beautiful eyes you have, I love your gaze)

Back (EN): What did you mean by that?
Notes: Asking for clarification. Can be confused or confrontational. Example: '¿Qué quisiste decir con eso? No entendí' (What did you mean by that? I didn't understand)

Back (EN): How sexy you are / You're so sexy
Notes: Direct sexy compliment. Example: 'Qué sexy eres cuando bailas' (How sexy you are when you dance)
Relationship definition question. Example: '¿Qué somos? ¿Somos novios o qué?' (What are we? Are we boyfriend/girlfriend or what?)

Back (EN): How lucky I am / What luck is mine
Notes: Expression of feeling fortunate. Can be sarcastic or genuine. Example: 'Qué suerte la mía conocerte' (How lucky I am to meet you)

Front (ES): Qué te gusta de este sitio
Back (EN): What do you like about this place?
Notes: Question about place preferences. Example: '¿Qué te gusta de este sitio? A mí me encanta el ambiente' (What do you like about this place? I love the atmosphere)

Colombian expression about something rough/harsh/difficult. Can be situation, texture, or taste. Example: 'Qué áspero ese examen' (How rough that exam was) or 'Qué áspero el clima' (How harsh the weather)
Request for someone to stay. Romantic or friendly. Example: 'No te vayas, quédate conmigo' (Don't go, stay with me)
Alternative: Stay with me | Romantic or friendly

Back (EN): Really fed up / Very tired of it
Notes: 'Re' = intensifier (very/really). 'Harto' = fed up. Example: 'Estoy re harto de este trabajo' (I'm really fed up with this job)
Time adverb meaning 'just now' or 'recently'. Example: 'Recién llegué' (I just arrived) or 'Recién casados' (Newlyweds)

Back (EN): Do you recommend something? / Any recommendations?
Notes: Asking for recommendation. Restaurant, activity, etc. Example: '¿Recomiendas algo de este menú?' (Do you recommend something from this menu?)
'Pegaditos' = diminutive of 'pegados' (stuck together). Dancing very close. Example: 'Bailemos reggaetón bien pegaditos' (Let's dance reggaeton really close together)
Mediocre response to '¿cómo estás?'. Example: '¿Cómo estás?' - 'Regular, he estado mejor' (How are you? - So-so, I've been better)

Back (EN): Should we repeat? / Let's do it again / Shall we go again?
Notes: Suggestion to repeat an experience. Example: 'Esa cita estuvo increíble, ¿repetimos?' (That date was incredible, shall we do it again?)
Statement of respect for someone's choice. Example: 'No estoy de acuerdo, pero respeto tu decisión' (I don't agree, but I respect your decision)

Back (EN): Let's go out for a walk alone
Notes: Invitation for private walk together. 'Solos' = alone/just the two of us. Example: 'Salgamos a caminar solos para hablar tranquilos' (Let's go for a walk alone to talk calmly)

Front (ES): Santa no te trajo pero qué regalo
Back (EN): Santa didn't bring you but what a gift
Notes: Romantic/flirtatious Christmas line. Implies person is a gift even though not from Santa. Example: 'Santa no te trajo pero qué regalo me dieron contigo' (Santa didn't bring you but what a gift they gave me with you)
Imperative challenge to seduce. Flirtatious invitation. Example: 'Sedúceme con tus palabras' (Seduce me with your words)
Ordinal number: second. Example: 'El segundo piso' (The second floor) or 'Un segundo' (One second/wait)
The number 60. Example: 'Sesenta mil pesos' (60,000 pesos)
The number 70. Example: 'Setenta años' (Seventy years old)

Front (ES): Si fueras lluvia yo sería Bogotá para te
Back (EN): If you were rain I'd be Bogotá to have you all the time
Notes: Romantic Colombian pickup line. Bogotá is very rainy. Means: If you were rain, I'd be Bogotá (rainy city) so I could have you all the time. Poetic cheesy compliment.

Front (ES): Si fueras una arepa te comería todos los
Back (EN): If you were an arepa I'd eat you every day
Notes: Romantic food metaphor. Arepas are eaten daily in Colombia. Means: I'd want you every day like Colombians want arepas. Playful/cheesy pickup line.

Front (ES): Si fueras una palabra estarías en el dic
Back (EN): If you were a word you'd be in the dictionary under 'perfect'
Notes: Cheesy romantic compliment/pickup line. Implies you're the definition of perfection. Classic corny line still used playfully.

Front (ES): Si la belleza fuera delito yo te daría c
Back (EN): If beauty were a crime I'd give you life in prison
Notes: Flirtatious pickup line. 'Cadena perpetua' = life sentence. Exaggerated compliment about extreme beauty being criminal. Colombian flirt culture.

Back (EN): I feel something nice for you
Notes: Confession of romantic feelings. 'Algo bonito' = something nice/beautiful. Example: 'Siento algo bonito por ti, me gustas mucho' (I feel something nice for you, I really like you)

Back (EN): Keep going like that / Continue like that
Notes: Encouragement to continue. Can be various contexts. Example: 'Sigue así que vas bien' (Keep going like that, you're doing well) or sensual: 'Sigue así, me gusta' (Continue like that, I like it)

Back (EN): Keep going / Continue straight / Go right past
Notes: Direction to continue without stopping. Example: 'Sigue de largo dos cuadras' (Keep going two blocks) or figurative: ignore/pass by something.
Adjective: next/following. Example: 'El siguiente en la fila' (The next in line) or 'La siguiente parada' (The next stop)
Slang affirmative. Playful version of 'sí'. Example: '¿Vamos?' - 'Simón' (Shall we go? - Yeah)
Dating/relationship term. Casual only. Example: 'Busco algo sin compromisos' (I'm looking for something with no commitments)
Relaxed approach statement. Example: 'Vamos sin presiones, tranquilos' (Let's go without pressure, relaxed)
Romantic metaphor meaning: I need you like water. Playful/poetic. Example: 'Sin ti me deshidrato porque eres mi agua' (Without you I dehydrate because you're my water)
Colombian slang affirmative. Very casual. Example: '¿Vienes?' - 'Sisas' (Are you coming? - Yeah)

Back (EN): It goes without saying / Needless to say
Notes: Expression meaning something is obvious. Example: 'Sobra decir que me encantó' (It goes without saying that I loved it)
Possessive statement. Romantic exclusivity. Example: 'Eres solo mía, de nadie más' (You're only mine, nobody else's)

Front (ES): Somos el uno para el otro
Back (EN): We're made for each other / We're meant for each other
Notes: Romantic statement about compatibility. Example: 'Somos el uno para el otro, lo siento en mi corazón' (We're made for each other, I feel it in my heart)
Relationship status statement. 'Novios' = boyfriend/girlfriend couple. Example: '¿Qué somos?' - 'Somos novios, ¿no?' (What are we? - We're dating, right?)
Time statement. Example: 'Son las tres de la tarde' (It's three in the afternoon)
Very formal Colombian address. Old-fashioned but still used in formal/respectful contexts. Example: '¿Cómo está su merced?' (How are you, sir/madam?)

Back (EN): Let's go up / We go up / Should we go upstairs?
Notes: Suggestion or statement about going up. Can be stairs, elevator, or euphemism. Example: '¿Subimos a mi apartamento?' (Should we go up to my apartment?)
Exercise suggestion OR sexual euphemism. 'Sudar' = sweat. Example: '¿Sudemos juntos en el gimnasio?' (Let's sweat together at the gym?) or euphemism for sex.
Literal: quench my thirst. Can be literal (give me drink) or metaphorical/flirtatious. Example: 'Sácame la sed, dame agua' (Quench my thirst, give me water) or flirty usage.
Affirmation with specification. Example: 'Sí así está perfecto' (Yes, like that it's perfect) or sensual: 'Sí así me gusta' (Yes, like that I like it)

Back (EN): Yes, I get it / Yeah, I understand
Notes: Colombian slang. 'Pillar' = to get/understand. Example: '¿Entiendes?' - 'Sí pilla' (You understand? - Yeah, I get it)

Back (EN): Get in / Get on / Come up
Notes: Imperative to get in/on vehicle or come up. Example: 'Súbete al carro' (Get in the car) or 'Súbete a mi cuarto' (Come up to my room)

Back (EN): I'll accompany you / I'll go with you
Notes: Offer to accompany someone. Caring gesture in Colombian culture. Example: 'Te acompaño a tu casa para que no vayas sola' (I'll accompany you home so you don't go alone)

Back (EN): I'll accompany you / I'll go with you
Notes: Offer to accompany someone. Caring gesture in Colombian culture. Example: 'Te acompaño a tu casa para que no vayas sola' (I'll accompany you home so you don't go alone)

Back (EN): Do you want to watch a movie? / Are you up for a movie?
Notes: 'Peli' = short for 'película' (movie). Colombian casual. Example: '¿Te animas a una peli en mi casa?' (Are you up for a movie at my place?)
Marriage proposal question. Example: '¿Te casarías conmigo? Quiero pasar mi vida contigo' (Would you marry me? I want to spend my life with you)

Front (ES): Te compro una pastica para el mareo
Back (EN): I'll buy you a pill for the dizziness
Notes: Caring offer. 'Pastica' = diminutive pill. 'Mareo' = dizziness/nausea. Example: 'Te ves mal, te compro una pastica para el mareo?' (You look bad, should I buy you a pill for the dizziness?)

Back (EN): I'll watch your spot / I'll save your seat
Notes: Offer to guard someone's place/seat. Common courtesy. Example: 'Voy al baño, ¿me cuidas el puesto?' (I'm going to the bathroom, will you watch my spot?)

Back (EN): Does something hurt? / Are you in pain?
Notes: Caring question about pain. Example: '¿Te duele algo? Te ves incómodo' (Does something hurt? You look uncomfortable)
Reassuring statement. Example: 'Te entiendo no te preocupes, todo va a estar bien' (I understand you, don't worry, everything will be okay)

Back (EN): Do you like it? / You like it
Notes: Question or statement about liking. Example: '¿Te gusta la comida?' (Do you like the food?) or sensual: '¿Te gusta así?' (Do you like it like this?)

Back (EN): Do you like it like this?
Notes: Seeking approval about specific way. Example: '¿Te gusta así o lo cambio?' (Do you like it like this or should I change it?) or sensual context.
Alternative: Like it this way? | Various contexts

Front (ES): Te gustaría ir a bailar el sábado
Back (EN): Would you like to go dancing on Saturday?
Notes: Date invitation. Colombian social culture loves dancing. Example: '¿Te gustaría ir a bailar el sábado? Conozco un lugar bacano' (Would you like to go dancing on Saturday? I know a cool place)

Back (EN): Did you like it? / You liked it
Notes: Past tense question/statement about liking. Example: '¿Te gustó la película?' (Did you like the movie?) or sensual: '¿Te gustó?' (Did you like it?)

Front (ES): Te llevo algo de comer o tomar
Back (EN): Should I bring you something to eat or drink?
Notes: Caring offer. Example: 'Voy a la tienda, ¿te llevo algo de comer o tomar?' (I'm going to the store, should I bring you something to eat or drink?)
Promise to send GPS location. Very common with WhatsApp. Example: 'Te mando la ubicación del restaurante ahorita' (I'll send you the restaurant location right now)

Back (EN): Does it tempt you? / Do you feel like it? / Are you in the mood?
Notes: Colombian expression asking if interested/tempted. Example: '¿Te provoca un helado?' (Do you feel like ice cream?) or '¿Te provoca salir?' (Are you in the mood to go out?)
Alternative: Colombian: are you in the mood?

Notes: Question or statement about staying. Example: '¿Te quedas a dormir?' (Are you staying to sleep?) or 'Te quedas conmigo' (You're staying with me)
Alternative: Are you staying | Question or statement

Back (EN): Are you staying to sleep? / Are you sleeping over?
Notes: Invitation to spend the night. Example: 'Ya es tarde, ¿te quedas a dormir?' (It's late already, are you staying to sleep?)

Back (EN): You feel good / I feel you're delicious
Notes: 'Rico' = delicious/good feeling. Sensual/intimate context. Example: 'Te siento rico cuando te abrazo' (You feel good when I hug you)

Front (ES): Te traigo algo para los cólicos
Back (EN): I'll bring you something for the cramps
Notes: Caring offer for menstrual cramps. 'Cólicos' = cramps. Example: 'Sé que te duele, te traigo algo para los cólicos' (I know it hurts, I'll bring you something for the cramps)

Back (EN): I'll see you at the entrance
Notes: Meeting place specification. Example: 'Te veo en la entrada del centro comercial' (I'll see you at the mall entrance)
Statement about having plenty of time. Can be relaxed or romantic. Example: 'No hay afán, tenemos toda la noche' (There's no rush, we have all night)

Serious relationship/playful flirtation. Example (serious): 'Tengamos hijos juntos' (Let's have children together) or (playful flirt): 'Eres tan hermosa, tengamos hijos' (You're so beautiful, let's have children)

Back (EN): Let's have a date / Let's go on a date
Notes: Date invitation. Example: 'Me gustas mucho, tengamos una cita' (I like you a lot, let's have a date)
Ordinal number: third. Example: 'El tercer piso' (The third floor)
Dietary restriction question. Example: 'Soy celíaco, ¿tienen algo sin gluten?' (I'm celiac, do you have anything gluten-free?)
Question about internet access. Example: '¿Tienes WiFi? Necesito trabajar' (Do you have WiFi? I need to work)
Asking for smaller bills/coins. Example: '¿Tienes cambio de cincuenta mil?' (Do you have change for 50k?)

Back (EN): Do you feel like it? / Are you in the mood?
Notes: Question about desire/willingness. Example: '¿Tienes ganas de salir?' (Do you feel like going out?) or sensual: '¿Tienes ganas?' (Are you in the mood?)
Sexual health question about condoms. Example: '¿Tienes protección o compro?' (Do you have protection or should I buy some?)
Cell phone signal question. Example: '¿Tienes señal? A mí no me carga' (Do you have signal? Mine's not loading)

Back (EN): Do you have size M? / Do you have medium?
Notes: Shopping size question. Example: '¿Tienes talla M de esta camisa?' (Do you have size M of this shirt?)
'Tipo' = approximately/around (Colombian usage). Example: 'Nos vemos tipo seis' (Let's meet around six)
Buffet description. Example: 'Es un restaurante de todo lo que puedas comer' (It's an all-you-can-eat restaurant)
Colombian diminutive. 'Fotico' = little photo. Example: 'Tomemos una fotico para el recuerdo' (Let's take a little photo for the memory)
The number 30. Example: 'Treinta mil pesos' (30,000 pesos)
Time: 3:30. Example: 'Son las tres y media de la tarde' (It's three thirty in the afternoon)
Three times. Example: 'Dame triple porción' (Give me triple portion)

Front (ES): Tu belleza es la octava maravilla del mu
Back (EN): Your beauty is the eighth wonder of the world
Notes: Romantic exaggeration. Seven wonders officially exist, so eighth = beyond all known wonders. Cheesy but endearing pickup line.

Front (ES): Tu mirada me pega más duro que el sol en
Back (EN): Your gaze hits me harder than the sun in Cartagena
Notes: Colombian romantic metaphor. Cartagena sun is intensely hot. Your look affects me more powerfully than intense Caribbean sun. Poetic/playful.

Front (ES): Tu papá es ladrón Porque robó las estrel
Back (EN): Your dad is a thief because he stole the stars from the sky to put them in your eyes
Notes: Classic ultra-cheesy pickup line. Implies eyes sparkle like stars stolen from sky. Very cliché but still used playfully in Colombian flirting.

Front (ES): Tu sonrisa brilla más que El Dorado
Back (EN): Your smile shines brighter than El Dorado
Notes: Colombian romantic reference. El Dorado = legendary city of gold. Your smile outshines mythical gold. Poetic/patriotic flirt.

Front (ES): Tu sonrisa debería venir con advertencia
Back (EN): Your smile should come with a warning
Notes: Flirtatious compliment. Implies smile is dangerously attractive. Example: 'Tu sonrisa debería venir con advertencia porque es peligrosa para el corazón' (Your smile should come with a warning because it's dangerous for the heart)
Observation about expressive eyes. Can be romantic or concerned. Example: 'Tus ojos dicen demasiado, sé que estás triste' (Your eyes say too much, I know you're sad)

Front (ES): Tus ojos son como el café colombiano osc
Back (EN): Your eyes are like Colombian coffee, dark and addictive
Notes: Colombian romantic coffee metaphor. Compares dark eyes to Colombia's famous dark addictive coffee. Patriotic poetic compliment.

Front (ES): Tus ojos tienen más magia que el Carnava
Back (EN): Your eyes have more magic than the Carnaval de Barranquilla
Notes: Colombian romantic reference. Carnaval de Barranquilla = Colombia's magical famous carnival. Eyes more magical than legendary festival. Patriotic flirt.
Imperative request. Can be innocent (touch my shoulder) or sensual. Context matters. Example (sensual): 'Tócame suave' (Touch me gently)
Diminutive request for small kiss. Example: 'Dame un besito antes de irte' (Give me a little kiss before you go)
Number 1 million. With pesos, ~$250 USD (2025). Example: 'Un millón de pesos' (1 million pesos)
Informal quantity expression. Example: 'Tengo un montón de trabajo' (I have a ton of work)
Diminutive of 'poco'. Very small amount. Example: 'Dame un poquito de agua' (Give me a little bit of water)
Colombian slang for large quantity. Example: 'Había un resto de gente' (There were a lot of people)
Casual agreement. Spanish slang. Example: '¿Vamos?' - 'Vale' (Shall we go? - Okay)
Invitation home. Can be innocent or romantic. Example: 'Vamos a mi casa a ver Netflix' (Let's go to my place to watch Netflix)

Back (EN): Let's go to a special place
Notes: Mysterious/romantic invitation. Example: 'Vamos a un lugar especial que te va a encantar' (Let's go to a special place you'll love)
Suggestion to travel by foot. Example: 'Vamos caminando, está cerca' (Let's walk, it's close)

Back (EN): Let's get to know each other more
Notes: Dating/relationship progression suggestion. Example: 'Vamos conociéndonos más antes de definir la relación' (Let's get to know each other more before defining the relationship)

Back (EN): Let's go slow / Let's take it slow
Notes: Suggestion for slow pace. Relationship or literal. Example: 'Vamos despacio con esto, sin apuro' (Let's take it slow with this, no rush)

Back (EN): Let's go slowly / Nice and slow
Notes: Diminutive of 'despacio'. Very slow/gentle. Example: 'Vamos despacito que no hay afán' (Let's go slowly, there's no rush) or sensual context.

Back (EN): Should we take an Uber or walk?
Notes: Transportation decision. Example: 'Está cerca, ¿vamos en Uber o caminamos?' (It's close, should we Uber or walk?)

Back (EN): Let's go for a little coffee
Notes: Colombian coffee invitation. 'Cafecito' = diminutive. Social ritual. Example: 'Vamos por un cafecito para conversar' (Let's go for a little coffee to talk)

Back (EN): We're leaving now / We're on our way out
Notes: Present continuous departure. Example: 'Ya vamos saliendo, llegamos en 10 minutos' (We're leaving now, we'll arrive in 10 minutes)

Front (ES): Vamos temprano para evitar el sol fuerte
Back (EN): Let's go early to avoid the strong sun
Notes: Beach/outdoor planning. Colombian sun is intense. Example: 'Vamos temprano para evitar el sol fuerte de mediodía' (Let's go early to avoid the strong midday sun)

Back (EN): Let's see / We'll see how it goes
Notes: Non-committal response. Example: '¿Salimos mañana?' - 'Vamos viendo' (Should we go out tomorrow? - We'll see)
Number 20,000. With pesos, ~$5 USD (2025). Example: 'Veinte mil pesos por el almuerzo' (20k pesos for lunch)
Number 21. Example: 'Veintiuno de mayo' (Twenty-first of May)

Back (EN): Shall we watch Netflix? / Let's watch Netflix
Notes: Common date/hangout suggestion. Can be euphemism. Example: '¿Vemos Netflix en mi casa?' (Shall we watch Netflix at my place?)
Imperative to approach. Example: 'Ven acá que te quiero mostrar algo' (Come here, I want to show you something)

Front (ES): Ven acá que no hemos terminado
Back (EN): Come here, we're not done yet
Notes: Statement about unfinished business. Can be conversation or intimate. Example: 'Ven acá que no hemos terminado de hablar' (Come here, we're not done talking)
Imperative invitation. 'Vente' = reflexive come. Example: 'Vente conmigo a la fiesta' (Come with me to the party)
Tag question seeking agreement. Example: 'Está rico, verdad que sí?' (It's good, right?)
Literal: old. Colombian slang: dude/friend. Example: 'Qué más, viejo' (What's up, dude) NOT about age in slang context.
Continuation question or filler. Example: '¿Y entonces qué pasó?' (And then what happened?)

Back (EN): I'll pay / It's on me / My treat
Notes: Offer to pay. Example: 'Yo invito esta vez, tú pagaste la última' (I'll pay this time, you paid last time)

Front (ES): Yo pongo la música tú eliges el lugar
Back (EN): I'll provide the music, you choose the place
Notes: Collaborative planning. Division of responsibilities for date/gathering. Example: 'Yo pongo la música tú eliges el lugar para la fiesta' (I'll provide the music, you choose the place for the party)

Colombian slang for sketchy/rough person. Can be negative or affectionate among friends. Example: 'Ese man es muy ñero' (That guy is very sketchy) or among friends: 'Qué más, ñero' (What's up, thug/buddy)
Adjective: last/final. Example: 'El último bus' (The last bus) or 'Por última vez' (For the last time)
